metadata.title: Nano-structured Antimicrobial Surfaces: From Nature to Synthetic Analogues

sections.text:
The scientific and industrial interest in antimicrobial surfaces has significantly increased in recent times. This interest is largely in response to the persistent microbial contamination of industrial and, importantly, medical implant surfaces. Bacterial contamination of implant surfaces often leads to infection at the implant-tissue interface, and with the prevalence of increasing levels of antimicrobial resistance; the treatment of these infections is becoming far more challenging. Recently, many naturally occurring, high-aspect-ratio surface topographies have been discovered that exhibit high levels of biocidal efficacy. These include epicuticular lipid nano-architectures that are formed on the surfaces of insect wings, such as cicadae and dragonflies. The antimicrobial activity of such surfaces has been found to be a consequence of the physical interactions taking between the nanoscale topography of the substrate and the attaching pathogenic cells, meaning that the activity is independent of biochemical surface functionality. Importantly, these desirable surface properties can be translated to synthetic biomimetic surfaces, which, when mimicked, lead to a substantial increase in the antimicrobial properties of such surfaces. This paper reviews the recent advances in understanding the basis of these mechanical antimicrobial mechanisms, and discusses the progress being made towards the fabrication of optimised, biocompatible, synthetic analogues.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Antibacterial, and more widely antimicrobial, resistance is an escalating medical issue that poses a threat to global public health [1, 2]. The continued misuse of antibiotics, together with the rapid evolution of multi-resistant microbial pathogens, has led to a significant increase in therapy-resistant diseases [3-5]. The consequence is that conventional therapies that have been routinely used to control pathogens are increasingly being rendered ineffective. This issue is particularly evident in post-operative patients who have undergone biomedical implant surgeries, due to the successful colonisation of multi-resistant pathogenic species at the transplant-tissue interface. In these patients, a so-called “race to the surface” occurs at the implant surface, in which eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells compete for surface
colonisation. Unfortunately, in a majority of cases, the dominant cell is more likely to be a pathogen.
Microbes will preferentially migrate towards, adsorb to, and colonise a solid surface [6-8]. This surface aggregation, and subsequent microbial proliferation, is commonly referred to as biofilm formation [6-8]. During this process, microorganisms undergo distinct biological changes, during which they form a self-produced matrix of extracellular polymeric substances (EPS). This matrix forms the foundation of a biofilm, which facilitates cell-cell and cell-surface adhesion at abiotic surfaces, while providing a protective environment for microbial pathogens. While biofilms have been extensively studied within a number of natural environments (soils, aquatic ecosystems, food sources), biological tissues, industrial settings, water piping systems, and on medical implants and instrumentation, they still represent a significant issue for many other applications.
The formation of a robust biofilm on a biomedical device for implantation can be extremely detrimental. The presence of microorganisms within a biofilm often leads to post-surgery complications, including implant-associated infections (both acute and chronic), implant rejection, and in extreme cases, death [1, 2, 9-11]. Biofilms can result from either perioperative procedures (introduction and adhesion of microbes during surgery) or postoperative procedures (microbial infection, which occurs during hospitalisation). Of great concern is that biofilm associated infections have been reported to affect around 10% of patients having undergone medical implant surgery in the United States alone, resulting in nearly 100,000 deaths per year. As such, this problem has been described as a “public health crisis” by the Infectious Diseases Society of America (ISDA) [1]. These adverse effects, coupled with the continual evolution of antimicrobial resistant microbe strains, means that on many occasions, implant-associated infections cannot be treated by conventional methods (antibiotic, fungicidal and anti-inflammatory agents) often requiring further corrective
surgeries, without the guarantee of success. Hence, medical procedures previously thought to be routine and low-risk now have an increased risk of adverse outcomes, which is becoming a significant world-wide concern.
Extensive research has focussed on mitigating the development of biofilms at the implanttissue interface. This research has often targeted the design and fabrication of next-generation biocompatible, microbial resistant surfaces [12]. Here, the aim is to design a surface that has the ability to inhibit the attachment of microbes, effectively halting biofilm formation and, inturn, preventing any subsequent infection of surrounding tissue [9]. The fabrication of such surfaces generally falls into one of two categories; the first uses chemical approaches, in which the surface is chemically modified, derivatised, functionalised, or coated with a biocidal material (nanoparticles [13-15], polymers [16-19], antibiotics [20, 21], among others [9, 19]). The second uses physical methods, wherein the surface architecture (topography) is modified in order to physically resist microbial colonisation. Although both methods have resulted in the formation of surfaces that have exhibited promising antimicrobial efficacy, chemical and coating methods have been shown to have several significant drawbacks; incorporation of antibiotics into the surface can result in antimicrobial resistance being developed, which is expedited by the nurturing environment of the biofilm. Coating methods can introduce potentially toxic materials into the body, causing significant concerns with regard to tissue toxicity and the development of periods of insufficient chemical activity. Conversely, high-aspect-ratio antimicrobial surfaces utilise naturally occurring, surface chemistry-independent, physico-mechanical mechanisms to control microbial growth. Such surfaces offer a sustainable, safe alternative surface for the prevention of biofilm formation, possessing an unfavourable surface topography or surface chemistry that either prevents the initial attachment of microorganisms or exterminates them on contact at the implant-tissue interface.
The aim of this article is to provide an overview of the current advances in antimicrobial surface technology. Traditional chemical methods of fabricating antimicrobial surfaces are briefly discussed. Following this, conventionally used implant materials such as titanium are reviewed, with recent steps being taken to minimise the formation of biofilms on their surfaces being highlighted. Current research into naturally occurring biocidal surfaces is then discussed, establishing avenues for the synthetic adaptation of these surfaces. Finally, recent advances into the production of biocompatible, biomimetic antimicrobial surfaces for exploiting naturally occurring biocidal surfaces are compared and evaluated.

sections.heading: 2. Antimicrobial Surfaces
sections.text: The formation of biofilms on solid surfaces has been recognised for the better part of a century [22]. In recent decades, biofilm formation has become a world-wide research challenge [1, 4, 5, 23, 24] because the instances of both antimicrobial resistance and postoperative infection are substantially and dramatically increasing. These increases have meant that a greater degree of research focus has been directed towards the development of microbe-resistant surfaces that have the capacity to prevent the formation of biofilms. Such unique surfaces are of particular interest in the design of biomedical implants due to the current relatively high risk of infection associated with implant surgeries.

sections.heading: 2.1 Bactericidal or Antifouling Surface?
sections.text:
In a recent review article, the difference between antibiofouling and bactericidal surfaces was highlighted, and the importance of using the correct terminology when discussing antimicrobial substrates was emphasised [9]. Briefly, the term ‘antibiofouling’ refers to the presence of a surface that is inherently resistant, or has the ability to limit the attachment of microbes. This property generally results from either an unfavourable surface architecture for
attachment or the presence of an unattractive surface chemistry for the attaching microbial species, each of which limits the extent of cell surface adhesion that takes place. ‘Bactericidal surfaces’ are different in that they act to disrupt any cells that have adsorbed onto the surface, resulting in the death of the cells. Bactericidal surfaces possess characteristics that can either physically or chemically disrupt the cell morphology, often utilising a combination of the two mechanisms.

sections.heading: 2.2 Commonly Used Medical Substrates
sections.text:
Titanium and titanium alloy materials represent the industry standard for surgical grade implant materials. Other commonly used implant materials include silicone [21, 25], ceramics [19], polymeric materials [9, 16-20] and stainless steel [17, 26, 27], among others [21, 25]. The choice of implant material to be used for a given application is dependent on a combination of function-specific properties, including inherent biocompatibility, inert chemistry, ease of biointegration, toxicity, strength, durability and resistivity to corrosion [25]. Despite the existing advanced understanding of the function-specific properties of these materials, the osseointegration of medical implants is still adversely affected by the in vivo formation of biofilms at the implant-tissue interface [6-8, 28]. As such, surface modification techniques that limit or prevent the attachment of microbes to implant surfaces have received a considerable degree of scientific interest [9, 19]. In general, this avenue of research has focussed on developing either micro/nano-fabrication approaches to alter the surface topography, or additive methods involving the application of surface coatings for titanium, titanium derivatives, and other model surfaces. The relationship between surface structure and microbial attachment has been investigated on a range of model substrates [26, 27, 29-50] possessing a range of surface characteristics including surface roughness, smoothness and grain size [26, 37-41, 47], nano-patterning or
nano-architecture, other surface characteristic variables (geometry, size, height, periodicity, aspect-ratio, surface irregularity) [29, 31-36, 42, 50], the incorporation of multi-ordered/scale structuring [29, 31-36, 42, 51] and substrate chemistry [26, 27, 43-49]. The results obtained throughout these studies allow the conclusion to be drawn that the micro/nano-topography of the surface plays a critical role in determining the extent of microbial attachment that will take place on the substrate. An in-depth understanding of these parameters would allow substrate manufacturers to tailor-make antimicrobial surfaces that can minimise or prevent the formation of biofilms, or even allow the synthesis of a surface that has the capacity to kill any microbes that come into direct contact. Importantly, the respective antifouling or microbiocidal efficacy of the substrate is highly dependent on both the architecture and chemistry of the surface, together with the nature and characteristics of the microbe itself. Although broad-spectrum antifouling and bactericidal or (more broadly) biocidal surfaces are highly desirable, a surface that is capable of completely preventing biofilm formation does not currently exist.
For typical metallic surfaces, the role of surface roughness on bacterial attachment has been thoroughly investigated [9, 26, 39, 45, 52-54]. Modulation of the attachment of microbes onto a surface is both microbe- and surface roughness-dependant, as microbial surface attachment is a complex process that is controlled by the chemical composition of the surface, its native charge, degree of hydrophobicity, roughness, geometry and surface free energy. In addition, cell attachment is controlled by the molecular structure of the microbe, its surface charge, hydrophobicity, ability to produce extracellular substances, and whether any cell-appendage interactions take place with the surface [54]. Initially, it was thought that the formation of ultra-smooth surfaces would result in a limited extent of bacterial adhesion. Conversely, substrates with increased levels of surface roughness were observed to be subject to increased degrees of biofilm formation [55, 56]. Review of the relevant literature, however, reveals this
model to be problematic; a consensus is difficult to reach due to a distinct lack of systematic studies, in addition to conflicting results being reported. This has limited the understanding of microbe-surface interactions and has resulted in a considerable amount of contention within the field. For example, an early study of the attachment of Staphylococcus epidermidis (S. epidermidis) cells onto titanium surfaces with variable degrees of surface roughness reported that identical adsorption behaviours would be observed on surfaces with roughness values ranging between 1.25 µm and 0.43 µm. A later study [27] reported that bacterial attachment occurred to a limited degree on stainless steel surfaces with an average roughness of 0.6 µm, but greater on substrates possessing either lower or higher degrees of surface roughness. More recently, studies by Ivanova et al. [57] and Truong et al. [39] both highlighted that a substantial increase in bacterial attachment would take place on titanium surfaces that possessed an average surface roughness below 1.2 nm. Similar results have been reported for glass surfaces with nano-scale surface roughness [46, 49]. Whitehead et al.[53] assessed the comparative attachment of Pseudomonas aeruginosa (P. aeruginosa) and Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) bacterial cells on titanium dioxide surfaces with variable degrees of nano-roughness. This work first established the different extents of attachment of spherical (S. aureus) and rod-shaped (P. aeruginosa) bacteria in response to surface roughness; The S. aureus cells exhibited greater levels of attachment onto surfaces with an average nano-roughness of 8.7 nm compared to surfaces with an average nano-roughness of 43.6 nm, while P. aeruginosa exhibited an inverse behaviour [53]. Ivanova et al. [37] continued this work, providing a systematic investigation of S. aureus and P. aeruginosa attachment to molecularly smooth titanium oxide with varying degrees of nano-roughness. The results were complementary to those of Whitehead et al.[53], revealing the dissimilar attachment behaviour for the two different types of bacteria. The variation in attachment behaviour was attributed to the differences in membrane rigidity and therefore
ability for the cellular membrane to stretch, which is a function of cell morphology, that is, whether the bacteria were rod-shaped or spherical. The spherical cells were less easily deformed, meaning they could adhere more effectively to smoother surfaces, and vice-versa. As this review is focused on the physical processes that govern the effectiveness of antimicrobial surfaces, an in-depth discussion of microbial adsorption mechanisms and the formation of biofilms will not be included, however several informative review articles that discuss these phenomena are available [54, 56, 58, 59]. The effect of variations in the surface nano-topography of substrates on the resulting extent of microbial attachment will be discussed below.

sections.heading: 2.3 Surface Coatings
sections.text:
A biofilm, which is composed of bacteria, fungi, viral bodies, or a combination of pathogens, often forms when a foreign material, such as an implant, is introduced into the human body. This results in short- or long-term infections, which can lead to implant rejection, failure and, in extreme cases, patient death. For this reason, many researchers have commenced designing biomaterials that inhibit pathogenic surface-adhesion and subsequent proliferation. One common approach for mitigating biofilm formation is to selectively coat a surface with an antimicrobial or antibiofouling material. Here, the rationale is to either inhibit microbial surface attachment or kill the microbial cells at the point at which they first attach to the surface, which prevents the subsequent formation of a biofilm. A vast array of surface coatings, possessing varying efficacy with regard to antimicrobial behaviour, have been investigated. These include biocompatible polymers [60], antimicrobial peptides [20, 61], polycations of quaternary ammonium salts [19], antimicrobial and antimicrobial-infused coatings [21, 28, 30, 62-66], nanoparticles and nanomaterials [66-69] and metal-based coatings that have been shown to prevent the attachment of microbial cells [66]. It should be
noted that these approaches are not without their disadvantages. In some cases, patients developed sensitivity to the antibiotic dose, or pathogenic mutation took place, resulting in the formation of antibiotic resistance to the surface coatings [25].

sections.heading: 2.4 Antibiotic Coatings
sections.text: Initial research into antimicrobial surfaces focussed on the addition of antimicrobial substances to medical implant surfaces [21, 30, 62], with the rationale to be the prevention of biofilm formation via the surface-based, proximal delivery of antimicrobial agents. In general, antimicrobial-infused biodegradable surface coatings are applied to a surface such as titanium. The antimicrobial compound is then slowly released, killing surface-bound microbes. For example, hydroxyapatite, a commonly used coating to promote osseointegration, has been infused with a variety of antibiotics and applied to an implant surface, resulting in the formation of a substrate that possessed varying degrees of antimicrobial efficacy [63-65]. Similarly, biodegradable polymers such as polyurethane, polyphosphoester, and poly(D,L-lactide) have been investigated as support media for the delivery of antimicrobial agents at tissue-implant interfaces [66]. These methods have several disadvantages; the ability to release antimicrobial agents from such surfaces is finite, and therefore will fall below the effective inhibitory concentration over time [28]. In addition, the release rate needs to be precisely controlled. If the release rate is too high, the resulting high concentration of antimicrobial agent can lead to acute tissue toxicity at the implant interface. Conversely, if the release rate is too low, the antimicrobial agents would be rendered ineffective [65]. Importantly, the continual use of high doses of antimicrobial agents has the disadvantage that multi-drug resistant microbes evolve [28]. For these reasons, the use of antimicrobial compounds at the tissue-implant interface is not an optimal method for imparting sustainable protection of an implant surface.

sections.heading: 2.5 Polymer Coatings
sections.text:
The attachment of a surface polymer layer or brush onto a substrate can mitigate the formation of biofilms via two mechanisms: either by providing a physical surface barrier, which resists the adhesion of microbes, or by imparting microbiocidal effects to the surface, effectively chemically exterminating pathogens upon contact [18, 20, 70, 71]. The various methods for producing surface polymers vary, but commonly used methods include covalent bonding and non-covalent tethering, often achieved using atom radical transfer polymerisation (ARTP) [9, 66]. A range of polymer morphologies have been investigated for their antimicrobial properties, often utilising cationic polymers because they mimic the amphiphilicity and antimicrobial functionality of peptides, while allowing the synthesis of these polymers in a way that is inexpensive and scalable. For example, poly(b-lactam),[72] poly(vinyl-N-hexylpyridinium) [17, 73], N-alkylated poly(ethyleneimines) [73], polyacrylate derivatives [70], chitosan [74] and poly-L-lysine [74] have been shown to have the ability to limit the formation of biofilms on a range of surfaces. The action of such antibacterial polymers is to disrupt the negative charge of a bacterial cell membrane, which induces cell lysis, resulting in cell death.
The biocidal efficiency of a polymer surface coating has been shown to increase with the molecular weight of the polymer [73], although controlling the molecular weight and polydispersity of the polymer within the surface layer has proven difficult. The work of Lee et al. [16] has allowed these parameters to be more tightly controlled, utilising ATRP methodologies to attach quaternised ammonium groups to glass and paper substrates. Such polymer surface layers demonstrated substantial levels of antimicrobial capacity, with surface layers possessing precisely controlled molecular weight and polydispersity being synthesised.
Many commonly investigated antimicrobial polymers have been shown to exhibit limited levels of biocompatibility, meaning that in vivo applications are also limited [75]. For example, quaternised ammonium cation polymer coatings often develop a “graveyard” of dead microorganisms, the presence of which can trigger an immune system response. These drawbacks have led to the development of biocompatible polymers [60, 71, 75, 76] with the aim of creating multifunctional antimicrobial, self-cleaning, and antifouling surface coatings. While showing promise, these studies are still in their infancy and require further investigation.

sections.heading: 2.6 Antimicrobial Nanomaterials
sections.text:
Nanoparticles [14, 15, 32, 66, 68, 69, 77-80] and nano-rods [67] have shown remarkable antimicrobial and biocidal activity towards a broad spectrum of Gram negative and positive infectious bacteria [13-15, 69, 77, 78, 81, 82] and even fungi [68]. As such, the incorporation of certain nanomaterials at tissue-implant interfaces has been widely considered to be a major factor in avoiding post-operative infection. Nanomaterials derived from silver [32, 66, 69], gold [15, 77], iron (III) oxide [68], zinc oxide [14], calcium oxide [78], titanium dioxide [78], magnesium oxide [79] and copper oxide [80], among others [78], have been extensively researched as being effective device coatings, wound dressings and in cosmetics and food storage applications [83]. In the design of biomedical devices, nanomaterials are usually suspended within a matrix of surface-bound material, such as a polymer, or chemically immobilised to the surface, which enables the slow release of the antimicrobial agent. Here, the rationale is that the antimicrobial materials will eliminate pathogens in close proximity to the implant interface, preventing the formation of a biofilm.
The biocidal activity of certain nanomaterials is thought to arise from a combination of effects, including the cell uptake of dissolved ions from the nanomaterials, degradative
particle-cell interactions, the nanoparticle size, shape, and surface charge, all of which are enhanced by the inherently large active surface area [78, 82]. The precise biocidal mechanism arising from these materials is complex in nature and is both microbe and nanomaterial dependant. As a result, the precise mechanism responsible for the biocidal activity is still somewhat speculative. For silver nanomaterials, the most highly investigated materials, evidence is mounting to suggest that the biocidal action is solely dependent on the release of dissolved silver ions (known to be toxic to microbes) and the subsequent microbe-ion interactions [13, 81]. This feature may be common amongst nanomaterials, but further investigation is needed to confirm this hypothesis.
While microbes are unlikely to develop resistance against nanomaterials, several studies have revealed that metal nanomaterials induce acute tissue toxicity in humans. This has resulted in their use being limited and remains an ongoing concern [84]. In general, very small concentrations of metal ions are considered safe, but their basal toxicity is confounded by an inability to precisely control the nanomaterial release kinetics, particle loading concentration and subsequent accumulation in human tissue.

sections.heading: 3. Natural Occurring Antibacterial Surfaces: A new paradigm
sections.text:
Microorganisms have had millennia to evolve complex adaptive mechanisms to successfully colonise abiotic surfaces; however, evolution works concordantly, meaning that many naturally-occurring surfaces have also developed their own protective mechanisms towards pathogenic infestation. Such natural surfaces exploit their micro- and nano-structural features, arranged in varying topographies, to impart biodical properties. In addition, these nanoarchitectures impart multi-functionality, affording a broad spectrum of favourable properties, often including the ability to self-clean [51], exhibit superhydrophobicity [85] and possess antibiofouling properties [9, 85, 86]. Common examples of surfaces that exhibit combinations
of these behaviours include: insect wings, such as those of cicadae [10, 86-90], damselflies [11, 91] and dragonflies [31, 92], shark skin [93-95], gecko feet [96-98] and plant leaves, most famously the lotus leaf [51, 99]. Initially, this antibiofouling action was attributed simply to the superhydrophobicity of the surface, which affords the surface the ability to selfclean, a mechanism exemplified famously by the lotus leaf. If a water droplet comes in contact with the multifunctional surface nano-structure of the top surface of a lotus leaf, it exhibits a very high contact angle and small sliding angle, both a condition for superhydrophobicity and low-adhesion functions. After contact, near-spherical water droplets form and roll across and eventually fall off the leaf, collecting and removing foreign material in the process [85]. More recently, a number of studies have revealed the existence of superhydrophobic surfaces that possess an unexpected functionality, such as the ability of naturally-occurring nano-patterned surfaces to exhibit antibacterial behaviour. This property has been shown to arise from a number of complex, surface specific mechanisms [9, 10, 31, 51, 86-93, 96-103].
Ivanova et al. [86] first studied the bactericidal properties of the naturally occurring, selfcleaning surfaces of cicada wings. This work characterised the adhesive behaviour of P. aeruginosa ATCC 9027 cells on the surfaces of the Psaltoda claripennis cicada. These wing surfaces have native periodic nano-topographies with near-hexagonal symmetry, which are comprised of an array of spherically capped, conical, nano-scale pillars (see Figure 1a) [86]. Nano-pillar features are now known to be common among cicadae, but the dimensions (height, spacing, and diameter) vary between species [90]. The nano-pillars on the surface of Psaltoda claripennis cicada wings are 200 nm in height, 100 nm in diameter at the base, and 60 nm in diameter at the cap, with an inter-pillar spacing of 170 nm (centre to centre). Despite initial thoughts that the wings would be resistant to bacterial contamination due to their superhydrophobicity, the cicada wings were found to be poorly antibiofouling, with P.
aeruginosa cells adhering in large numbers to the wing surface (see Figure 1e). Nonetheless, the cicada wing surfaces prevented the formation of a biofilm for an unexpected reason; the high-aspect-ratio nano-topography of the surface was highly bactericidal, physically disrupting the bacteria upon attachment to the surface, resulting in the cells being completely killed within a few minutes. Figure 1e displays a scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of the adsorbed P. aeruginosa cells, which highlights the underlying surface penetrating the bacterium [86].
To identify the origin of the bactericidal action, and determine whether it was physical, chemical or hydrophobic in nature, the wing surface was altered; a 10 nm thick layer of gold was sputter-coated onto the cicada wings, significantly changing the surface chemistry and hydrophobicity, while retaining the native nano-pillar surface topography. Importantly, the bactericidal surface activity was unaffected by these surface modifications, meaning that the observed bactericidal action was physical in its origin. In light of this result, a physicomechanical mechanism was proposed, whereby the high-aspect-ratio nano-pillars ruptured and consequently killed the bacterial cells upon surface adhesion. This allowed the conclusion to be drawn that the cicada surface topography serves a dual purpose, imparting both bactericidal and hydrophobic properties to the surface, with the two properties not being intrinsically linked. Hasan et al. [101] provided a further insight into this phenomenon, conducting a wide spectrum bacterial study on the biocidal efficacy of cicada wings. The results revealed that the nano-structure of the wings surface was capable of consistently killing Gram negative bacteria (Branhamella catarrhalis, Escherichia coli, P. aeruginosa, P. fluorescens), while Gram positive bacteria (Bacillus subtilis, Planococcus maritimus, Staphylococcus aureus) remained resistant, and that the biocidal activity was independent of bacterial shape.
Figure 1. Top Row: 4 µm × 4 µm TEM images of a) Cicada Wings (Psaltoda claripennis), b) Dragonfly Wings (Diplacodes bipunctata) c) Damselfly wings (Calopteryx haemorrhoidalis), and d) Gecko Skin (Lucasium steindachneri), which reveal the respective native high-aspect-ratio nano-topographies on the wing surfaces. Middle Row: e, f, & g) 3.5 µm × 3.5 µm and h) 12 µm × 12 µm TEM images of the wing surfaces when inoculated with (e, f, & g) Pseudomonas aeruginosa ATCC 9027 (P. aeruginosa) and h) Porphyromonas gingivalis (P. gingivalis). Bottom Row: Schematic representation of bacterial attachment onto the cicada wing nano-pillars showing i) cellular approach, j) initial adhesion buckling the cell membrane, k) the apparent rupture of the cell wall in the region suspended between the nano-pillars, and l) cell collapse (death) onto the nanopillars. Images i-l are screenshots of an animation of the mechanism consistent with the proposed biophysical model. Figures a & e were adapted from reference [86] with permission from John Wiley and Sons, copyright (2012). Figures b & f were adapted from reference [100] with permission from Royal Society of Chemistry, copyright (2016). Figure c & g were adapted from reference [103] with permission from Springer, copyright (2017). Figures d & h were adapted from reference [97] with permission from Elsevier, copyright (2015). Figure i, j, k & l were adapted from references [87] with permission from Elsevier, copyright (2013). A theoretical study performed by Pogodin et al. [87] supported the initial observations of Ivanova et al. [86] with regard to the biophysical model of cell rupture. This model suggested that the bacterial cell adhesion onto the nano-pillar structures of the cicada wing caused the cell membrane to distort and split, subsequently causing cell death (see Figure 2) [87]. Further, the model highlighted that the bacterial cell adsorption behaviour was dependent on the underlying surface geometry, and importantly, was critical in determining the antibacterial efficacy of the nano-patterned surfaces [87]. In turn, the cell membrane was
stretched in the regions suspended above the pillars, and when a critical degree of stretching was induced, the cell ruptured, causing death [87]. Since this work was first published, numerous naturally occurring biocidal surfaces have been identified to possess antibacterial [10, 31, 86-88, 90-93, 96-98, 100-103] and even fungicidal [104] behaviour with varying degrees of efficacy [10, 11, 31, 86-88, 91-94, 96-98, 101, 102]. A selection of these surfaces is shown in Figure 1, highlighting the different nano-architectures responsible for imparting the biocidal properties to the surface. The common thread linking these surfaces is that highaspect-ratio nano-structures were responsible for these properties.
Optimising the spatial orientation and nano-patterning of biocidal features is paramount to the improvement and implementation of this technology. Indeed, several studies have begun to investigate the relationship between the surface nano-topography and the resultant antimicrobial efficacy. Kelleher et al.[89] compared the bactericidal activity of cicadae wings from three species (Megapomponia intermedia, Ayuthia spectabile, and Cryptotympana aguila), and towards the Gram negative bacteria, P. fluorescens. This semi-systematic study of three naturally nanotopography variants suggested that the bactericidal surface activity increased as the nano-pillar pitch and diameter was reduced, forming shorter and sharper nano-pillars. Alternatively, this could be rationalised as follows: an increase in the degree of nano-pillar-cell interactions resulted in a greater bactericidal activity of the nano-structure. These results were in good agreement with the theoretical model proposed by Xue et al [88]. This study concluded that short, sharp nano-pillars induced a greater strain on the bacterial membranes, which in-turn displayed a greater degree of antimicrobial behaviour than their taller counterparts.
Although the initial studies have been limited to the study of bacteria on such surfaces, the end objective in the development of many substrates is to develop broad-spectrum surfaces that limit or prevent the colonisation of both bacteria and other pathogenic species, namely
fungi and viruses. The differences in prokaryotic bacterial cells and eukaryotic fungal cells are distinct, both in their surface attachment behaviour and in their physical/chemical structure [105]. Despite these dissimilarities, recent studies of fungi being adsorbed onto nano-textured insect wing surfaces have revealed that such surface have shown promising antifungal behaviour, similar to the cell-rupturing effect observed for adsorbed bacteria [104]. Specifically, the fungus Saccharomyces cerevisiae (S. cerevisiae) was found to be incapacitated by the native nano-pillar structures of cicada (Magicicada septendecim and Tibicen tibicen) wings and snapdragon (Progomphus obscurus) flower surfaces, with moderate to good anti-fungal efficiency being observed in each case [104]. An adhesiondependent correlation was proposed, where surfaces with higher degrees of high-aspect-ratio nano-structures were found to exhibit greater lethality to fungal cells. This result is commensurate with the model proposed for the bactericidal activity of cicada wings [10, 86- 90, 101]. While preliminary, this study represented an appreciable step forward in the development of broad-spectrum micro-biocidal surfaces, but further research and perhaps the identification of a new range of fungicidal surfaces, whether natural or synthetic, would be required to ensure a good understanding of the underlying mechanisms responsible for the antifungal behaviour would be obtained. Naturally occurring biocidal nano-patterns provide the blueprint for a new class of antimicrobial biomaterials. Natural surfaces cannot be tailored, customised, or optimised, because they are, by nature, determined by evolution. Once understood, however, these surfaces could be optimised through the development of synthetic mimics. The following section discusses the recent advances made in the incorporation of biocidal nanostructures, based on natural surfaces, into synthetic analogues.

sections.heading: 4. Learning from Nature: Artificial Mechano-biocidal Surfaces
sections.text:
Naturally occurring biocidal surfaces have provided scientists with the template for the nextgeneration antibiotic-independent, antimicrobial substrates. Here, the common link between antimicrobial surfaces is the presence of a continuous array of high-aspect-ratio nanoarchitectures, which vary in topography. The high-aspect-ratio nano-structures impair the formation of biofilms via a mechanical biocidal mechanism that acts to physically disrupt the cell walls of pathogenic species upon surface adhesion. Consequently, these structures have inspired the fabrication of a range of biomimetic analogues utilising a range of nanofabrication techniques. The objective in these studies is to harness the antimicrobial mechanisms found in nature for use in the development of biomedical devices, in addition to other applications, which require the minimisation or elimination of pathogenic contamination, such as in the design of next-generation implant material [106-109], water treatment devices [110], medical sutures [111], and surgical instruments [31, 32, 34].
The work of Ivanova et al. [107] initiated the research into the design of a range of synthetic, mechano-responsive biomimetic antimicrobial surface analogues. In their landmark study, the profile of silicon substrates was altered to incorporate high-aspect-ratio nano-protrusions (see Figure 2a) that mimicked those found on the wings of one species of dragonfly, specifically Diplacodes bipunctata [107]. The resulting substrate, called ‘black silicon’ (bSi) differed in nano-architecture from that of the dragonfly wings, in that the nano-protrusions were sharper and more discretely arranged, displaying a lower degree of clustering. The nano-pillar diameters ranged between ~20 – 80 nm with a bimodal distribution, and were a height of ~500 nm, which was approximately twice that of the dragonfly wing nano-pillars. The bSi surface was found to be highly bactericidal against both Gram negative and Gram positive bacteria, and endospores, exhibiting killing rates of up to ~450,000 cells min -1 cm -2 . Notably,
the bSi substrate often displayed higher degrees of bactericidal efficacy than their biological blueprints (cicada and dragonfly wings), establishing the realistic opportunity to develop effective, optimised, next-generation antimicrobial nano-materials. The substantial difference in composition of the naturally occurring biocidal surfaces (coated with epicuticular waxes) and the bSi (comprised mostly of SiO2) further confirmed that the biocidal mechanism was a process that was independent of the surface chemistry.
Figure 2. a) 5 µm × 4 µm top down SEM image of the bSi surface. The inset shows a micrograph tilted at 53° to reveal the side profile of the sharp nano-pillars. b) Two stage colonization evaluation of the pathogenic bacteria P. aeruginosa and fibroblast-like monkey kidney tissue (COS-7) cells: 1) SEM and corresponding confocal laser scanning microscopy (CLSM) images of a bSi surface (such as shown in (a)) infected with P. aeruginosa for 6 hr (right images). The altered bacterial morphology and CLSM image analysis confirm that the bacteria were dead after the 6 hr incubation period. 2) Pre-infected surfaces seeded with COS-7 cells (left images). Bacteria and eukaryotic cell were grown simultaneously and monitored for 7 days. It was demonstrated that COS-7 cells were able to attach and grow on the pre-infected bSi surfaces, while only debris of the bacterial cells was found after 1 day of co-culturing on the bSi surfaces. c) SEM images of multi-colonies (8 noncompetitive strains) of gut bacteria inoculated on a replica gecko skin surface demonstrate the bactericidal function. The inset shows a side view of the native (uninfected) spinules. d) Top down SEM image of P. aeruginosa cells on a titanium surface modified with nano-wire arrays e) SEM image of Diamond nano-cone surface infected with P. aeruginosa cells. f) AFM image of Escherichia coli (E. coli) adsorbed onto poly(methyl methacrylate) nano-pillars. The deformation of the rod-shaped cell indicates that it is dead. Figures a, b, c, d, e and f were adapted from references [107], [112], [98], [31], [12], and [113] with permission from Nature Publishing Group, copyright (2013), American Chemical Society copyright (2016), Nature Publishing Group copyright (2017), Nature Publishing Group, copyright (2015), AIP Publishing LLC, copyright (2016), and AIP Publishing LLC, copyright (2015), respectively. The fabrication of biomimetic, biocompatible, mechano-responsive antimicrobial analogues represents an exciting prospect, particularly for the design of antibacterial medical implants;
however, one important question remained as to whether eukaryotic (human) cells were adversely affected by the action of the bSi surface topography. In vivo implant studies [109, 112] have demonstrated the biocompatibility of bSi, where animal trials highlighted that no inflammatory response was observed in the host for both ocular and general tissue environments, which supports their use as biomedical materials. This phenomenon is discussed further in section 5, as well as the bactericidal efficacy of nanostructured surfaces towards Gram positive versus Gram negative cells in section 7.
The utilisation of mechano-responsive antimicrobial surfaces is not limited to the design of implant materials; broader areas of interest include, but are not limited to, food-hygiene applications, sterility improved surfaces (clean-room surface coatings), surgical implement nano-patterning (surgical blades), and water treatment devices. In these applications, the antimicrobial behaviour of nanostructured surfaces can be harnessed to reduce the extent of pathogenic contamination in an extracorporeal setting. Indeed, very recently Wang et al. successfully integrated bSi within a bactericidal microfluidic device [110]. Here, a reusable cell, utilising bSi, was shown to effectively rupture E. coli cells from contaminated water. With adequate scalability, this could represent a viable method of cleaning bacteria- infected water sources without the need for cleansing chemicals, which is highly desirable, particularly for developing nations.
A prerequisite to enable synthetic analogues to be used in the design of medical devices is biocompatibility and scalability. To this end, numerous investigations have continued the quest for identifying biomimetic synthetic antimicrobial surfaces. Figure 2 shows a selection of microscopy images highlighting key biomimetic surface designs and their antimicrobial activity towards various bacteria. A variety of potential biocompatible substrate materials have been investigated, including surface modified titanium [29-31, 33-36, 114] and titania [90], gold [115], poly(methyl methacrylate) [113], graphene [116], diamond [12], diamond
coated bSi [108] and a range of biocompatible polymers [93, 95, 98]. These studies have utilised a variety of nano/micro-fabrication techniques to manufacture laboratory-scale substrate samples, including reactive-ion beam etching [12, 107], plasma etching [108], laser ablation [107], microwave plasma chemical vapour deposition [12], nano-imprint lithography [113] and bench-top nano-templating [98], among others [90, 98, 113, 115], with the aim of optimising the biocidal properties of the high-aspect-ratio biocidal nano-structures found in nature. These advances towards the biomimetic synthesis of antimicrobial surfaces are summarised in Table 1. The wide range of materials being used for these systems reinforces the importance of the physical nature of the biocidal mechanism initially observed on the surface of dragonfly wings. Several of these studies [31, 34, 36, 90] have concurrently probed the response of eukaryotic cells to the underlying biocidal substrate surfaces, revealing their growth to be unaffected, or even in some cases encouraged by the presence of the modified surface. These results confirm that nano-biocidal surfaces represent an excellent prospect in the design of biomedical implants. Some recent research has reported data pertaining to substrates that possess high-aspect-ratio nano-pillars coated with antibiotic agents [114]. While being effective, these surfaces are susceptible to the same issues regarding antibacterial resistance, as previously discussed.
A preliminary study [35] of the fungicidal activity of mesopore-textured titanium has demonstrated the possibility of producing mechano-responsive surfaces that are both antibacterial and antifungal in their nature; however, due to the complex nature of fungisurface interactions, further studies will be required to fully assess the extent of fungicidal efficacy possessed by these surfaces. Unfortunately, the ability to transfer biocidal nanostructures that have been successful produced on a small scale (up to a few centimetres) to larger scale implant surfaces has yet to be performed, however this scaling is a fundamentally important step towards the ability to implement this technology on an extensive scale.

Optimisation of the specific nano-architecture present on surfaces is paramount in producing highly efficient antimicrobial substrates, and eventually their wide-spread use in medical and industrial applications. It is largely the arrangement of the surface nano-features that dictates the level of micro-biocidal action that can take place on the surface. Currently, there is a lack of systematic data on this topic reported in the literature, and as such an in-depth insight into the relationship between surface nano-architecture and the antimicrobial behaviour exhibited by some surfaces is not currently possible; nonetheless, cross-referencing the currently available data provides some important insights into the ideal geometry and spatial arrangement of antimicrobial nano-features. Consideration of the geometry and arrangement of surface features is appropriate, as it has been demonstrated that activity of mechanoresponsive biocidal surfaces is independent of the surface chemistry. Dickson et al. [113] fabricated PMMA surfaces containing nano-pillars with varying degrees of inter-pillar
spacing and slightly different pillar heights. This work suggested that short, closely spaced nano-pillars exhibited a greater degree of bactericidal activity towards E. coli compared to larger, widely spaced nano-pillars. This observation is in agreement with the previously discussed experimental [89, 106] and theoretical models [87, 88] of naturally occurring bactericidal surfaces. A more recent study of the antimicrobial activity of diamond nanocones performed by Fisher et al. [12] further supported these conclusions, suggesting that multi-hierarchical, densely populated, high-aspect-ratio domains increase the biocidal activity of some nano-textured surfaces compared to that obtained using more uniform arrangements. Tsimbouri et al. [34] provided a bactericidal contrast between differing spatial densities of titania nano-wires, finding that less densely bundled arrangements of nano-wires exhibited greater levels of bactericidal activity towards infective doses of P. aeruginosa cells. These results were supported by a similar study performed by Diu et al. [90], however the results from these studies are in stark contrast to those obtained in the previously discussed nanopillar studies, where it was observed that more densely arranged nano-pillars were more effective at killing bacterial cells coming into contact with the surface. These differing observations highlight the importance of considering the efficiency of the initial microbial cell adhesion to a surface in determining the resulting degree of antimicrobial activity, which is still a highly debated topic in the literature.

sections.heading: 5. Biocidal Efficacy Towards Gram Positive and Gram Negative Bacteria
sections.text:
A common misconception surrounding the biocidal behaviour exhibited by high-aspect-ratio surface technologies is that the surface itself punctures the colonising pathogen. In actuality, the inverse scenario is true: upon surface adsorption the microbe must deform in response to the nanostructured surface. This deformation induces a membrane stress, which if sufficiently strong, fractures the cell membrane, causing death [10, 87, 88, 90, 92, 104, 118]. This means
that the biocidal efficacy of a high-aspect-ratio antimicrobial surface is directed by the surface specific spatial geometry and is microbial species dependent. As such, the process of cell lysis is a complicated phenomenon, encompassing the specific cell membrane rigidity, thickness and size, turgor pressure, affinity for surface colonization, and cell-surface and cellcell interactions upon adsorption.
This is best highlighted by the work of Hasan et al. [101], who tested the bactericidal activity of cicada wings against seven bacterial species with variable properties, covering every combination of cell morphology (rod-shaped and spherical) and cell wall structure (Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria). Here, the surfaces were highly bactericidal against Gram negative cells, regardless of their morphology, while Gram positive cells remained resistant to the biocidal surface structures. These results demonstrate the variable activity of specific surfaces towards Gram positive and Gram negative bacteria, which differ considerably in their physical properties and cell wall composition. Gram positive cells possess thick layers of peptidoglycan, meaning that they are generally more rigid than Gram negative cells, which have much thinner, and less rigid membranes. These results were consistent with the mathematical modelling performed by Pogodin et al. [87], suggesting that cell rigidity was an important factor in determining whether the cell were susceptible to the action of the nanostructured surfaces.
Gram positive cells are, however, not completely immune to the action of high aspect ratio nanostructured surfaces, with many biomimetic surfaces containing short, sharp nanofeatures successfully being able to induce cell lysis. As a general comment, this is likely to be why many studies in this field ignore the testing of Gram positive cells when evaluating the antimicrobial efficacy of their surfaces.

sections.heading: 6. Bactericidal Mechanism of Mechano-biocidal Surfaces
sections.text:
While it is generally accepted that the mechanism responsible for cell death at nanostructured surfaces is mechanical in nature, a clear understanding of the underlying mechanism is yet to be conclusively determined, with several different mechanisms having been proposed [10, 87, 88, 90, 92, 104, 118]. The different mechanisms being proposed can be largely attributed to the complex, adaptive nature of microbial cells, which creates the possibility of a multitude of cell-surface interactions taking place. Initially, the process was defined simplistically: the high-aspect-ratio nano-structures were thought to puncture the pathogenic cell on surface contact, leading to cell death [86]. Since then, experimental [10, 86-90, 92, 101, 104, 118] and theoretical [10, 87, 88] studies have advanced understanding in the area. Combined, these studies suggest that the biocidal mechanism is a complex interplay between the deformation of microbial membranes during surface adhesion [104], the microbial cells subsequently stretching, and then rupturing in the valleys between the surface features [10, 87, 88, 118], directed cell penetration of the nano-architectures [86, 107, 119], EPS-induced adhesive forces [92] and the specific microbial species (adhesive mechanism, mobility, cell wall structure, and adaptability)[120]. Despite these studies having been performed, several questions still remain: what is the precise role of the EPS formation? Are the processes of membrane deformation and cell adhesion intrinsically linked to the surface topography (i.e. do the adhesive forces differ as a function of the geometry of the surface nano-topography)? What is the role of the microbial non-specific adhesion processes (nonfimbrial, fimbrial and discrete polysaccharides)? How does cell wall rigidity affect the resultant biocidal activity? Does cell mobility influence the process? How does the biocidal efficacy change with nano-feature architecture and density?
Diu et al.[90] provided an alternative insight into the mechanism responsible for the antimicrobial behaviour of some surfaces, suggesting that both cell mobility and the degree of membrane stretching play a significant role in the antimicrobial behaviour of a surface. In addition, a recent article by Bandara et al. [92] reported the utilisation of a combination of advanced microscopy techniques in the investigation of the bactericidal mechanism of dragonfly wings (specifically Orthetrum villosovittatum) towards E. coli bacteria. Native dragonfly wing surfaces contain multi-hierarchical structures, with populations of cylindricalshaped nano-pillars with two distinct heights being present, which impart the bactericidal behaviour to the surface [102]. Peak-force AFM measurements explored the bactericidal mechanism, attributing the cell membrane damage to a combination of bacterium EPS being strongly attached to the surface nano-pillars, and a shear force (stretching) response initiated when the bacterium attempt to escape the unfavourable surface topography. The study performed by Bandara et al. [92] unfortunately did not provide sufficient experimental evidence to support the explanation provided that EPS production played a part in the overall biocidal mechanism. This conclusion was drawn, since the proposed mechanism could not be used to explain the rupturing of non-motile cells, such as S. aureus, that are incapable of migrating away from unfavourable substrate surfaces. To adequately assess the role played by the EPS, parallel studies could be performed using both regular cells and mutant bacterial cells that do not allow the usual EPS-response; such a study would represent an important focus of future work in this area. The mechanism proposed by Bandara et al. is not definitive and therefore would require further investigation to allow a conclusion to be reached.
7. Selective Biocidal Activity: Prokaryotic versus Eukaryotic Cell Adhesion
As implant materials, nanostructured antimicrobial technologies are not effective if cells of the host organism cannot survive when coming into contact with their high-aspect-ratio surfaces. To this end, several studies have been commenced to investigate the interaction of mammalian (model host) cells with high-aspect-ratio surfaces. Interestingly, in vitro studies [109, 112] of eukaryotic cell behaviour in contact with bSi nanopillars (see figure 2B) have shown high levels of biocompatibility with these nano-fabricated substrates. Pham et al. [112] first demonstrated that eukaryotic cells were capable of growing over, and successfully colonizing, nanostructured bSi surfaces that had been pre-infected with live pathogenic bacteria. Here, the study observed the so-called “race to the surface”, a term first coined by Gristina [121]. The “race” describes the competition in surface colonization of the host cells and the ever-present pathogens at the implant-tissue interface. If the tissue cells were able to colonise the surface before the pathogenic cells, then the implant became protected from any subsequent pathogenic invasion, promoting successful tissue integration. If the pathogenic cells primarily colonized the surface before the tissue cells, biofilm formation would take place, which would likely result in post-operative complications such as infected tissue, inflammation, implant failure, or in some cases, patient death. In this study, monkey kidney tissue (COS-7) cells were brought into contact with the high aspect ratio nano-pillars present on bSi surfaces that were pre-infected with viable S. aureus and P. aeruginosa cells to elucidate the surface response (see Figure 2b). The COS-7 cells were found to preferentially proliferate over the bSi surface, with 100% confluence noted after 7 days of incubation, while the pathogenic bacteria were successfully exterminated by the surface. The biocidal selectivity of bSi nanostructured surfaces towards prokaryotic (bacterial) cells, while facilitating eukaryotic cell (COS-7) proliferation, was attributed to two main differences in cell structure: firstly, eukaryotic cell are much larger in size than bacteria, and develop filopodia (fibril based protrusions) during the initial cell-surface attachment. These
protrusions are an important cue parameter in the initial attachment of cells to the nanostructured substrates, acting as anchorage points to the underlying nanostructure protrusions and distributing the cell mass across a larger surface area. Secondly, combined CLSM and freeze-fracture SEM, together with TEM investigations [122], have suggested that eukaryotic membranes are capable of distorting and engulfing themselves along the surface nanopillars without damaging the internal cytosolic material comprising the cells. As such, the observed modulation in biocidal efficacy between the eukaryotic and prokaryotic cells is largely based on their size and rigidity. The larger mammalian cells are capable of accommodating the imposed surface stress, while the bacterial cells cannot accommodate this stress and hence do not exhibit the same degree of resilience to the action of the surface. This result [112], combined with the observed biocompatibility [112, 117], provided a promising result in support of the nano-topography present on the surface of bSi being incorporated into the design of medical implant devices to ensure these devices were unable to sustain a biofilm. A related study was later reported that extended the existing understanding of the way by which human plasma protein (human serum albumin and fibronectin) adsorbed onto the nano-structured surfaces present on bSi [109].

sections.heading: 8. Outlook and Conclusions
sections.text:
Antimicrobial surfaces have the ability to repel microbial cells, mitigate their attachment, or exterminate them upon surface adhesion [9-12, 16, 19, 36, 77, 87, 88, 93, 97, 100, 103, 108, 111, 115]. The two former approaches have proven to be unsustainable; either the mechanisms responsible for repelling bacteria are susceptible to the development of antibacterial resistance or for mitigating their attachment do not adequately inhibit the formation of biofilms [16, 19, 77, 82, 115]. Naturally occurring surfaces such as insect wings, which possess the ability to kill cells once they have attached to the surface, represent an
excellent prospect and template for the development of synthetic antibacterial surfaces [51, 86, 96-98, 100, 102-104]. Such surfaces contain high-aspect-ratio nano-pillars that act mechanically to rupture any pathogenic cells attaching to the surface, killing the microbe. The precise geometry of the surface topographies varies between substrates, and hence the nature of these nano-architectures ultimately determines the extent of antimicrobial efficacy, adhesion behaviour, and biocidal selectivity towards a given microbial species [12, 34, 87-89, 108, 113]. Unlike chemical-based methods for preventing bacterial attachment, microbes cannot readily develop resistance to this approach due to the mechanical basis of the biocidal mechanism [9, 11, 19, 87]. This is particularly relevant for the development of biomedical implant materials, where pathogenic biofilms can form on substrate surfaces prior to, or during, surgical procedures [1, 4, 21, 25, 30, 111].
In developing antimicrobial implant materials, antimicrobial nano-structures must be effectively transferred to the surfaces of biomimetic, biocompatible synthetic analogues. To date, significant in-roads have been made towards this outcome, with investigators successfully reverse-engineering antimicrobial surface topographies and successfully transferring these onto a range of appropriate surface materials using a variety of fabrication techniques [9, 10, 12, 93, 96, 98, 107-110, 115]. These relatively recent advances are summarised in Table 1. Titanium [31, 33, 35, 36], titania [29, 89, 114], bSi [107], and polymer [90, 98, 113, 115] substrates, amongst others [12, 80, 90, 98, 108, 113, 115], with different nano-topographies have been investigated, revealing that these surfaces can exhibit high levels of antimicrobial activity. Systematic studies of the relationship between the nanofeature geometry and the extent of antimicrobial efficacy are, however, still largely absent. To this end, active researchers should be encouraged to expand their studies on such surfaces to include a wider range of microbes, including investigations of the interaction of bacteria, fungi, viruses, and parasites with these substrates, while broadening the surface parameters
used in investigation. Many studies will report only one, or in some cases a few seemingly random surface geometries, which does not overall allow surface parameter optimization with a view to enhancing the antimicrobial surface activity.
The biocidal mechanism of nano-structured surfaces is known to be physical in origin [87, 88], but the precise physico-mechanism is still under substantial debate [90, 92]. Fundamental properties that need to be further understood include the role of surface geometry (feature spacing, height, aspect-ratio, size, multi-scale order, and feature angle, among others) and the nature of the cell-surface adhesion in controlling the biocidal activity of a substrate. To elucidate the origins of cell-surface interactions, recent advances in single cell force spectroscopy could provide a valuable insight into the mechanisms taking place [123]. These factors are not readily elucidated, largely because microbe-surface interactions are complex in nature, involving dynamic forces, biological responses, cell-cell and cellsurface interactions, release of EPS during biofilm formation, among other factors that are both microbe and surface-nano-structure dependant [10, 87, 88, 90, 92, 104, 118]. For these reasons, a comprehensive mechanism to explain the antimicrobial behaviour of some surfaces is difficult to describe. It is unlikely that a single, universally effective antimicrobial surface structure will be determined, but this should not discourage further research in this area; even a slight increase in the broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity has the potential to limit the instances of biofilm formation on substrate surfaces. Determining the underlying mechanism responsible for antimicrobial activity will undoubtedly enable further optimisation of surface parameters; overcome key performance limitations, and the realisation of wide-spread commercial viability of synthetic antimicrobial surfaces. Such insights will require information to be obtained from fundamental, computational and experimental studies of the process.
The relationship between the spatial geometry of surface nano-architectures and the resultant microbiocidal activity is still not clear; however, developing this understanding is paramount for wide-spread adaptation of the technology. While not conclusive, comparison of individual studies does provide some insight into this phenomenon: it appears that multihierarchical, closely spaced, sharp nano-pillars may impart a greater degree of biocidal activity towards both Gram positive and negative bacteria [12, 87-89, 106, 108, 113].
The practical application of such surfaces in biomedical implants requires that they be biocompatible [21, 25], but this need not be the case in the development of high-throughput devices for screening antimicrobial surface activity. Rapid surface geometry optimisation using non-conventional production methods such as nano-3-D printing [124], nanotemplating [98] or nano-lithography [125] could be achieved. Employing these methods could have the potential to remove the constraints associated with the use of conventional surfaces (such as the time and expense associated with the fabrication and production of these substrates), increasing the ability to isolate highly antimicrobial nano-architecture geometries. Once identified, the optimal surface architecture could be transferred to a biocompatible substrate for further use. For non-biocompatible, biocidal nanostructured surfaces, applications beyond their use as implant materials are possible where pathogenic contamination minimisation is needed upon contact. These include food-hygiene applications, antimicrobial surface coatings, surgical implements, such as surgical blades, and water treatment devices.
The significant levels of bactericidal activity displayed by the synthetic antimicrobial surfaces produced thus far provide an excellent blueprint for the development of nextgeneration, mechano-responsive implant materials. The last hurdle to be overcome prior to the wide-spread utilisation of these surfaces is the ability to readily fabricate, and importantly up-scale the production of such nanomaterials. This technology represents a significant
advance in the production of safe, micro-biocidal surfaces for biomedical and industrial applications, for which optimisation of the surface architecture is undoubtedly the key to producing broad-spectrum antimicrobial surfaces.
